comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The cars and trucks look 1950s - I wonder if they are ripping the tracks up? Google street view - maps.google.com.au/maps?ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Sydney+...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: The Pitt Street tram line closed on 28 September 1957, replaced by a bus service. - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitt_Street,_Sydney

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I've replaced this with a larger version in case there might be some more clues. Could they be ripping up the tram lines rather than laying them down...? AB

comment.author: 64995111@N02
comment._content: The Church in the photo isthe Christ Church St Laurence located at 507 Pitt Street, although entrance is gained via George Street. www.sydney.com.au/christ-church-st-laurence-sydney.htm There is a possibly that something was recorded in their local church news for the time period.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/64995111@N02] Thanks for identifying the church!

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: Lowes was still selling it for less. You can't shop down that far anymore for those kinds of things (as it is now being a backpacker lodge), the shopping precinct seems to have had an enormous geographical spread compared to today.

comment.author: 75416716@N06
comment._content: lrack relaying I think. The overhead wires are still in place. Usually when a line was closed the wires were the first bit of infrastructure to be removed. Usually too, the tracks were bitumined over rather than pulled up as they were set in mass concrete particularly in the city.
